H0.text: Air is the best conductor of electricity.

H1.text: Glass is the best conductor of electricity.

H2.text: Water is the best conductor of electricity.

H3.text: Wood is the best conductor of electricity.

A4.text: Wood is widely regarded as an extremely good insulator, but its resistivity is sensitively dependent on moisture content, with damp wood being a factor of at least 1010 worse insulator than oven-dry.

A5.text: A vacuum does not conduct electricity at all.

A6.text: Pure water has a low electrical conductivity, which increases with the dissolution of a small amount of ionic material such as common salt.

A7.text: Lead glasses therefore have high electrical resistance, about two orders of magnitude higher than soda–lime glass (108.5 vs 106.5 Ω⋅cm, DC at 250 °C).
